Literature Review: The integration of vestibular and visual cues in the cerebral cortex plays a crucial role in navigation, visual processing, and perception. This literature review aims to explore recent findings on the cortical integration of these sensory modalities and their impact on spatial cognition and decision-making. Vestibular signals, despite their importance in various cortical functions, rarely enter our conscious awareness. However, recent research has shed light on the significance of these internal signals in cortical sensory representation and their contribution to sensory-driven decision-making, particularly in spatial navigation tasks. The integration of vestibular and visual information in the cortex has been shown to enhance both the neural representation and perceptual accuracy of self-motion and orientation. One of the key areas where vestibulo-visual integration has been extensively studied is the posterior parietal cortex (PPC). Noel et al. (2018) demonstrated that the PPC plays a crucial role in integrating vestibular and visual cues for self-motion perception. Their study revealed that disrupting PPC activity using transcranial magnetic stimulation impaired participants' ability to accurately judge their heading direction during combined vestibular and visual stimulation. The hippocampus, a region critical for spatial navigation and memory, has also been implicated in vestibulo-visual integration. Hitier et al. (2014) reviewed the anatomical and functional connections between the vestibular system and the hippocampus, highlighting the importance of vestibular input in maintaining spatial memory and navigation abilities. They proposed that vestibular signals contribute to the formation and updating of cognitive maps in the hippocampus. Recent advances in rodent research have provided valuable insights into the physiological and behavioral significance of vestibular signals in cortical processing. Cullen and Taube (2017) reviewed the neural mechanisms underlying the integration of vestibular and visual information for head direction representation. They emphasized the role of the thalamus and retrosplenial cortex in combining these sensory inputs to maintain an accurate sense of orientation. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) has emerged as another critical region for vestibulo-visual integration in spatial navigation. Jacob et al. (2014) demonstrated that MEC neurons in rats exhibit grid-like firing patterns that are influenced by both visual and vestibular cues. Their findings suggest that the MEC integrates multiple sensory modalities to create a coherent representation of space. The integration of vestibular and visual information also has implications for visual perception itself. Dokka et al. (2019) investigated how vestibular signals influence visual motion perception in humans. They found that vestibular cues modulate the perception of visual motion, particularly in situations where visual information alone is ambiguous or unreliable. The role of vestibulo-visual integration in decision-making processes has gained increasing attention. Angelaki et al. (2011) reviewed the neural computations involved in multisensory integration for perceptual decision-making. They proposed that the brain combines vestibular and visual cues in a statistically optimal manner to improve the accuracy of self-motion estimates and subsequent decision-making. Recent technological advancements have allowed for more precise manipulation and measurement of vestibular and visual inputs in experimental settings. For instance, Klingner et al. (2016) used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate the cortical networks involved in vestibulo-visual integration during simulated self-motion. Their results revealed a distributed network of brain regions, including the insula, temporoparietal junction, and frontal eye fields, that respond to both vestibular and visual motion cues. The constant updating of self-motion information through vestibulo-visual integration has important implications for predictive processing in the brain. Laurens and Angelaki (2017) proposed a theoretical framework for how the brain combines vestibular and visual signals to generate internal models of self-motion. These models can be used to make predictions about future sensory states and guide rapid, navigation-related decision-making. In conclusion, the integration of vestibular and visual cues in the cerebral cortex plays a fundamental role in spatial navigation, visual processing, and perception. Recent research has highlighted the widespread nature of this integration across multiple cortical regions, including the PPC, hippocampus, MEC, and visual cortices. The constant updating of self-motion information through vestibulo-visual integration provides a basis for accurate sensory perception and predictions, which are crucial for navigation-related decision-making. Future research should focus on further elucidating the neural mechanisms underlying this integration and its implications for cognitive functions beyond spatial navigation.
